summary: In this 1956 Gold Coast Supreme Court case, the plaintiff (Amade) entered into a hire-purchase agreement with the defendants (F. and M. Khoury) for a lorry. The defendants lawfully seized the vehicle in December 1954 due to a £20 arrear in payments. Although the plaintiff later paid the £20, the court held he was not entitled to repossession because the agreement lacked a redemption clause allowing reinstatement upon payment of arrears. Additionally, two collateral agreements—evidenced by receipts for repairs and spare parts worth £380 15s. 6d.—remained unpaid, and their inclusion effectively extended the hire-purchase obligations. The court dismissed the plaintiff's claim for return of the lorry or damages and entered judgment for the defendants on their counterclaim for the outstanding amounts.
verdict: The plaintiff's claim was dismissed; judgment was entered for the defendants on both the claim and counterclaim.

jurisdiction.court: Supreme Court of the Gold Coast

rationaleHighlights: The hire-purchase agreement permitted seizure upon default, and no redemption clause allowed repossession after payment of arrears.
The defendants were within their rights to retain possession after lawful seizure.
Payment of the £20 arrear did not discharge the full obligation due to unpaid collateral agreements.
The receipts for repairs and spares constituted binding collateral agreements extending the original contract.
The plaintiff's argument on public policy was not pleaded and therefore could not be considered.
The defendants accepted the arrears payment but were not required to return the lorry as obligations remained outstanding.
The plaintiff had used the lorry for three years and caused damage, justifying the defendants' concern over property preservation.
The court found the agreements were properly explained and understood by the plaintiff.
